ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SEPARATE WATER METERS FOR STALLHOLDERS
(Installation)


    1. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Prime Minister if he will instruct the Public Utilities Board to install separate water meters for each stall in the Housing and Development Board Bendemeer Road Market at the Kallang Basin Estate Neighbourhood I, Phase 2, and in all markets and hawkers' centres where water supply is required by stallholders.

Column: 593



    The Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office (Tuan Haji Ya'acob Bin Mohamed) (for the Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not feasible for operational and economic reasons to install separate water meters for each stall either in the Housing and Development Board Bendemeer Road Market or in all markets and hawkers' centres. The total cost of the meter installation, distribution, maintenance and billing is high, and it is not justified by the small consumption of water of each stallholder or hawker.

    At hawkers' pitches and markets under the control of the Hawkers' Branch, Ministry of Health, a single meter has been supplied for the use of all the hawkers. All the stalls at each of the new hawkers' pitches at Dunearn Road, Orchard Road Car Park, Newton Circus, etc., have formed committees under the guidance of the Hawkers' Branch to look after their own interests and to work out their own administrative procedures. This arrangement has to-date been found to work satisfactorily. Perhaps the stallholders in the Housing and Development Board Bendemeer Road Market at the Kallang Basin Estate Neighbourhood I, Phase 2, should be advised to form a similar body to adopt such an arrangement.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Sir, can the Minister of State in the Prime Minister's Office say whether the Public Utilities Board will be prepared to provide public service if its profit goes above one cent from each stall-holder?

    Tuan Haji Ya'acob(In Malay): As I have said earlier on, it is uneconomical to put this project into operation.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Will the Minister of State inform the House if it is the opinion of the Housing and Development Board that each stall-holder should have his own water meter?

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may reply to that supplementary question. This is not so much a question of economy as a question of convenience for

Column: 594

all hawkers and stallholders concerned, as in the example given, in which they formed themselves into a committee and were served by one meter. This has been done in many housing estates by many hawkers' stalls, and I see no reason why this could not also be done in the case of the estate mentioned by the Member.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Mr Speaker, Sir, is this an introduction to a socialist way of life for one small sector?

    Mr Lim Kim San: It is not an introduction to a socialist way of life, but an introduction to a common-sense approach to problems.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION ACT
(Insurance coverage by employers)


    2. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Labour the number of workmen who have been insured by their employers in accordance with the Workmen's Compensation Act.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, statistics on the number of workmen who have been insured by their employers are not available. It should be pointed out that until the coming into force of the Workmen's Compensation (Amendment) Act in November, 1971, employers were not legally required to insure against their liability under the Act.

    It would, however, appear that most of the employers do have insurance policies to cover their workmen. From reports received from employers when submitting their accident reports, it is estimated that more than 95 per cent of the employers have insured their workmen under the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Act.

WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION ACT
(Insurance coverage by employers)


    3. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Labour if he will ensure that employers do insure all their insurable employees under the Workmen's Compensation Act.

Column: 595



    Mr Sia Kah Hui (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, steps will be taken by the Labour Ministry to ensure that employers do insure all their insurable employees under the Workmen's Compensation Act.

    Labour Inspectors when making their routine inspection will check that employers have insured themselves in respect of their liability under the Workmen's Compensation Act.

    The Ministry is also considering the possibility of requesting employers to submit returns to ascertain that they have insured themselves against their liability under the Workmen's Compensation Act. The necessary regulations and forms will have to be published and staff found to check the returns if this is to be done.

CRECHE FACILITIES FOR
KAMPONG TIONG BAHRU
(Sufficiency of)


    7. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Social Affairs, in view of the fact that the majority of the residents in Kampong Tiong Bahru are in the lower income group and require the facilities of a creche, if he plans to resite the creche at Moh Guan Terrace in Kampong Tiong Bahru and expanding its services; or, alternatively, if he will consider building a creche in Kampong Tiong Bahru.

    The Minister for Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are already adequate creche facilities, including a children's centre, in the Tiong Bahru and Kampong Tiong Bahru areas, which are, in fact, within the distance of approximately a mile of each other.

    There is no plan to resite the creche at Moh Guan Terrace because it is rendering a valuable service to working mothers in the Tiong Bahru area as well as Kampong Tiong Bahru. This creche has a capacity of 40 children, and its average daily attendance is 30. If this creche at Mob Guan Terrace has to be moved elsewhere, especially out of Tiong Bahru itself, I am sure the Member for Tiong Bahru will agree with me that the many working mothers in Tiong Bahru will be greatly inconvenienced by being deprived of the necessary creche facilities.

    While it is appreciated that some of the residents in Kampong Tiong Bahru may require the facilities of a creche, there already exists in the nearby Bukit Ho Swee estate a Government creche run

Column: 599

by the Social Welfare Department. The Bukit Ho Swee creche, which has a capacity of 120 children, has at the moment, an average daily attendance of approximately one-half its total capacity. As this creche is in close proximity to Kampong Tiong Bahru, there should be no difficulty for any resident of Kampong Tiong Bahru estate to avail herself of the services of the Bukit Ho Swee creche. In fact, there are already 20 children from Kampong Tiong Bahru attending this creche daily. And since there are still many places in this creche for the children of Kampong Tiong Bahru, there is no plan at the moment to build another creche in Kampong Tiong Bahru.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the land between Jalan Yasin and Lorong Sarina is private property and not a road-reserve. As the residents along these two roads already have access to either Changi Road or Jalan Eunos, the additional expenditure was considered not justified. The owner of this portion of Jalan Yasin will be required to make it up when he develops his land.

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [7th March, 19721, "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1972 to 31st March, 1973.". -[Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

2.53 p.m.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance's painless Budget, which was presented to this House last week, has been well received both inside and outside this House. What is most welcome is his declaration that no new tax measures, either directly or indirectly, are to be introduced for the next financial year.

Column: 602



He has, in fact, "sweetened" the painless Budget with certain tax reliefs in order to benefit the common man.

    The Budget Statement reflects the foresight of the Government and the soundness of its economic planning and its programmes of expansion in the past decade, and it exudes an atmosphere of quiet confidence for the future.

    The tribute which the Minister for Finance paid to the workers of all ranks and occupations for their contribution to the success of Singapore's economic development is very appropriate. Now that the workers can see for themselves the fruits of their past efforts and sacrifices, they should have the determination to work even harder to ensure a continuing, if not greater, prosperity and progress in the coming years.

    The actions of the Government, as reflected in the Budget Statement presented to this House, and elsewhere, have clearly shown that it is not oblivious to the part played by workers in the economic development of the Republic. As far as practicable, the Government has made every attempt to utilise the success of Singapore's economic development for social upliftment so that every citizen of Singapore, including the workers, will be able to cultivate a more gracious life-style that is in accord with their enhanced financial means. In this respect, the recent decision of the Government to increase the rates of the Central Provident Fund contributions and also to increase the remuneration of employees in the public sector in order to promote Government's home-ownership scheme for Singapore citizens, is highly commendable. It is natural that, with increasing economic prosperity, there should follow a rising level of our expectations which have manifested themselves in, for instance, the desire to own the house or flat in which we live, and also the desire for more and better facilities for recreational and cultural pursuits.

    The setting up of the National Wages Council, in which the Government, the National Trades Union Congress, and the employers are equally represented,

Column: 603

for the purpose of formulating guidelines on wages, indicates an awareness of the need for workers to be given an equitable stake in the fruits of the economic development and progress of Singapore. At the same time it is vitally important for the future of the Republic that wage increases should not be allowed to get out of hand or it would result in a vicious spiral of inflation which can only damage the interest of the Republic. The National Wages Council, therefore, has assumed a role of utmost significance not only to the workers but also to the rest of the people of Singapore, in that it serves as a regulator for the economic health of the Republic. In relation to the economy of Singapore itself and in relation to the competition among the developing nations of the world for foreign capital and investment, the difference between a rational and a chaotic wage policy can spell the difference between prosperity and disaster.

    While the recent statement on the wage policy of the Government and other indications point to an era of greater affluence for the workers of the Republic, the fear that wage increases for the workers would be more than swallowed up by price increases is still valid. Legislation for price controls may seem to be necessary in order to eliminate profiteering by traders, but there are other practical considerations which are likely to stultify such legislation. For this reason, the N.T.U.C, has decided to initiate measures, which are compatible with the limited resources at its disposal, to protect the workers against the ravages of profiteering by unscrupulous traders. One such measure is the establishment of CASE (Consumers' Association of Singapore) to promote a greater consciousness among the individual consumers in Singapore against exploitation by traders in respect of prices, qualities and quantities of goods and services offered for sale to the public. Another measure is the proposal to set up a Consumers' Co-operative which, by

Column: 604

offering goods and services to consumers at reasonable prices, will place the unscrupulous traders who charge extortionate prices at great risk.

    In his Budget Statement, the Minister for Finance stated that steps are being taken to streamline the Immigration procedures to ensure that persons who can positively contribute to the economy of Singapore are permitted entry into the Republic. It also appears that the Government is encouraging employers, both in the public and private sectors, to establish schemes for the training of workers within the industry as part of a scheme to develop and to use our own manpower resources to its maximum so as to reduce our dependence on foreign labour. On the face of it, the policies of the Government in this area seem to be correct. I must, however, draw the attention of the Government to the difference between the formulation of a policy and its actual implementation. While the grounds for formulating a policy have been given the most careful consideration, the manner in which it is implemented is, however, not given the same amount of detailed consideration, and is consequently likely to be fraught with abuses, some flagrant, some petty.

    Where the applicants are technicians and possess technical or scientific qualifications, no great difficulty is entailed in the evaluation of the economic significance of their talents. But where they possess skills which are based on aesthetic or popular taste, or fashion, for which there is no objective criterion, it frequently appears that the policy of the Government on the control of entry of foreign labour into the Republic is open to abuse.

    A case in point is the employment of foreign musicians. With the help of the Tourist Promotion Board, some hoteliers and impresarios, have, under the pretext of promoting tourism, succeeded in obtaining entry permits for foreign musicians who are, in fact, no better than our local musicians. Many such foreign musicians, who have not been able to make a name in their own countries or have yet to gain inter-national

Column: 605

national experience and reputation, are willing to take on jobs at very low wages. It is hard to believe that tourists who come to Singapore from the three main tourist countries, the United States, Japan and Australia, where their own artistes are of a much higher standard, are likely to return to be entertained with such inferior musical talent. As a result, there is resentment and frustration among the local musicians for being unable to earn a living in this trade or to obtain an opportunity to improve their skills for employment in the international market.

    Recently, when it became apparently necessary for an advertising firm to effect a retrenchment exercise, a local executive, not a foreign executive, was given the walking certificate, regardless of the fact that the local executive was much better qualified. In such a situation, it would be extremely difficult for the Immigration Department to form an opinion as to whether the advertising firm should have dispensed with the services of the foreign executive rather than the local executive. The talents of a good advertising executive cannot be readily measured by any objective criteria. My point is that if an employer wishes to employ a foreign executive in preference to a local executive, it would not be difficult for him to advance one pretext or another to convince the Immigration Department of the need for an entry permit for the foreign executive.

    All the abuses resulting from the present mode of implementation of Government's immigration policy in relation to foreign personnel, if left unremedied, would surely bring about a demoralising effect on the local personnel who are qualified to replace such foreign personnel. It is not only in the interests of our local technicians or executives but also in the interests of the Republic as a whole that the Government's immigration policy should be implemented in a constructive manner so as to give a fair balance between the need for foreign expertise and skill and the need to give our local citizens every opportunity to acquire such expertise and skill.

Column: 606



    It is my hope that the Government will be able to take the necessary steps to streamline our immigration procedures so as to eradicate the abuses in respect of the employment of foreign personnel. In my view, it will be a step in the right direction if the Government is able to set up a "consultative machinery" whereby the Immigration Department could form a reasonably correct judgment as to whether the skill of any foreigner is of any use to the Republic.

3.01 p.m.

    Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta)(In Mandarin): Sir, the present Budget is not only the third painless Budget in the last three years but it also provides six tax reliefs, especially in a situation of international monetary instability and the final phase of the British military withdrawal. This undoubtedly reflects our strong economic position and it provides a boost for the attraction of investment, both from Singapore and abroad. Obviously, the emphasis of the Budget is to meet the problems and the consequences of industrialisation and commercial development in the coming years. As the Minister for Finance has said, our aim is to transform Singapore which has an economic growth rate of 15 per cent into a regional centre for brain services and brain service industries within 10 years. This aim is very fitting to a country like ours. We should make full use of the good qualities of our people and try our best to develop industries which do not occupy large stretches of land, so that we may achieve and maintain an annual economic growth rate of 15 per cent. This will also help to complement the development of our neighbouring countries which have large expanses of territory.

    According to the Minister, earnings from tourism continued to grow and showed an increase of 17.2 per cent in 1971 as compared with that for the previous year, 1970. However, the Minister also said that the hotel occupancy rate has fallen from 73.5 per cent in 1969 to 70.7 per cent in 1970 and down to 65.4 per cent in 1971. This

Column: 607

shows that the hotel occupancy rate is going down while the number of tourists coming to Singapore is increasing. The Tourist Promotion Board should work out a solution, otherwise its expenditure on publicity and promotional efforts to attract more tourists will not be justified.

    Of the six tax relief measures, that for accelerated depreciation for industrial anti-pollution devices is the most meaningful to the health of our people. The other reliefs will not benefit our people as much as this one. Our people, be they property owners or otherwise, have the right to enjoy a clean and healthy environment. The Government is expecting a loss of $3.5 million in revenue by implementing these tax reliefs. This shows that the interest of the masses is not forgotten.
